tool.name: Sam/bam Validate:
tool.command:
rgPicardValidate.py -i "$input_file" --datatype "$input_file.ext" -d "$html_file.files_path" -o "$html_file" -t "$out_prefix" -e "$ignore" -b "$bisulphite" -m "$maxerrors" -y "$new_format" -j ${GALAXY_DATA_INDEX_DIR}/shared/jars/ValidateSamFile.jar #if $genomeSource.refGenomeSource == "history": -r "$genomeSource.ownFile" #elif $genomeSource.refGenomeSource=="indexed": -r "${ filter( lambda x: str( x[0] ) == str( $genomeSource.index ), $__app__.tool_data_tables[ 'all_fasta' ].get_fields() )[0][-1] }" #end if
#if $new_format.value == "sam": --sam "$out_file" #elif $new_format.value == "bam": --bam "$out_file" #end if

param.name: input_file
param.label: Input: sam or bam format short read data in your current history
param.help: If the select list is empty, you need to upload or import some aligned short read data from a shared library

param.name: out_prefix
param.label: Title for the tool run - use this remind you what the job was for

param.name: new_format
param.label: Cleaned Output file options - None, sam or bam
param.option: No 'clean' output file will be created - report errors only
Sam format - all flagged reads removed
Bam format - all flagged reads removed

param.name: bisulphite
param.label: Input file contains Bisulphite sequenced reads

param.name: refGenomeSource
param.help: If in doubt, choose built-in and read Picard/Samtools documentation
param.label: Reference genome - none, built-in or from current history?
param.option: No reference - NM tags will NOT be validated (see Picard documentation)
Use a genome (fasta format) from my history

validator.message: No reference sequences are available for the build associated with the selected input data

param.name: ownFile
param.label: Select a reference genome from history

param.name: ignore
param.label: Ignore these Picard Validate errors - select none, one or more

param.name: maxerrors
param.label: Maximum number of errors to output
param.help: Set to zero to see every durn one. Default value: 100

tool.help:
.. class:: infomark
**Syntax**
- **Input** is sam/bam format aligned short read data in your current history - **Title** is the title to use for all output files from this job - use it for high level metadata - **Output options** None=Just run the validator - do not produce a new output file sam/bam=Remove all flagged 'error' reads - **Bisulphite Treated** see Picard documentation http://picard.sourceforge.net/command-line-overview.shtml#ValidateSamFile - **Refseq** is the sequence you want to interogate - eg hg19 - can be Galaxy built-in or a special one from your history - **Maximum Errors** see Picard documentation http://picard.sourceforge.net/command-line-overview.shtml#ValidateSamFile - **Ignore chosen errors** See Picard documentation at http://picard.sourceforge.net/command-line-overview.shtml#ValidateSamFile
-----
.. class:: infomark
**Summary**
This Galaxy tool uses Picard to report and optionally filter out all reads with Picard detected errors.
Picard is supported through the SamTools project. This tool wraps Picard and is supported through the galaxy-bugs mailing list or by providing comments through the report form that appears automatically if a tool fails unexpectedly when you run it in Galaxy.
All the Picard tools are freely available and are documented at http://picard.sourceforge.net/command-line-overview.shtml#CollectAlignmentSummaryMetrics
-----

.. class:: infomark
**Why you might want to use this tool**
This tool provides a Galaxy interface to one of the Picard tools. Picard seems (in our hands) fragile to irregularities in data This tool allows you to see what's wrong and optionally remove all the relevant 'error reads' This is clearly an awful way to clean your alignments, but until someone can improve on this it will have to do
Send code please.
If your Picard jobs die, with or without some explanation, try this tool. You may optionally do a dry run and not create a 'clean' file Or you can choose to ignore one or more of the error flag reads if you have specific needs.
-----
